awd_abstract_narration:
The Northeast Bioengineering Conference (NEBEC) is one of the two longest continually running conferences in the United States in the arena of biomedical engineering (BME). Drexel University’s School of Biomedical Engineering, Science and Health Systems will host the 49th NEBEC March 30 – April 1, 2023. The NEBEC has historically been a student-centered conference. This tradition will be continued by providing opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to present their work. An undergraduate design competition will be followed by a career fair offering information and contacts for potential career paths for biomedical engineers. The overall theme of the conference will be “Enhancing Diversity in Biomedical Engineering.” Keynote speakers and session chairs were identified in 5 themed areas: (1) Extracellular Matrix, (2) Pediatric Engineering, (3) Immune Engineering, (4) Neuroimaging and Neuroergonomics, and (5) Biological Computing.  Activities are planned for high school students from under-represented groups and a round-table discussion will be held on efforts to increase diversity at universities and industry. This conference will expose students at all levels to leading edge research in biomedical engineering, foster interest in pursuing careers in biomedical engineering research and innovation, and provide networking opportunities with peers and with leaders in their fields.  

This award supports the 49th Northeast Bioengineering Conference, a region that is home to over 71 biomedical engineering programs.  The conference provides a unique opportunity for undergraduate and graduate student researchers in the field of biomedical engineering to present their research to a broad audience.  Historically, 60 75% of the participants are students and over 60% of the platform presentations are given by trainees.  The 49th Conference will feature over 200 poster sessions, of which 33% of the presentations are Senior Design Projects.  Over 270 abstracts were received from the expected on site attendance of more than 450 participants, with additional participants attending virtually.  A new feature of the 49th conference is the inclusion of efforts to promote diverse participation in the field of biomedical engineering by reaching out to high schools serving under-represented minorities in the Philadelphia region. The participating high school students will get to interact with current BME students to help them envision themselves taking that step in their education, and they will hear from recent graduates about the career paths available to them. The goal is to encourage them to pursue STEM careers.   The roundtable discussion of efforts to increase diversity in BME programs in the Northeast is expected to generate a whitepaper describing successes and challenges identified that will be distributed to BME program chairs nationally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Northeast Bioengineering Conference (NEBEC) is the one of the two longest continually running conferences in the United States in the arena of biomedical engineering (BME).  Drexel University’s School of Biomedical Engineering, Science and Health Systems hosted the 49th NEBEC March 30 – April 1, 2023

 

NEBEC has historically been a student-centered conference. We continued that tradition by providing opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to present their work. There was a total of 548 participants. 143 undergraduates participated in the Design Poster session, which had 65 posters. In addition to the undergraduates, there were 184 student participants. 59 submissions were chosen for oral presentations.

 

At NEBEC 2023, we had 5 Keynote lectures by outstanding leaders in their fields to highlight groundbreaking work in the conference theme areas of Neuroengineering, Mechanobiology, Pediatric Bioengineering, Bioinformatics, and Immunoengineering. 

 Jeffrey W. Ruberti, Northeastern University, Mechanochemistry of Durable Structure Formation in Animals: Opportunities to Engineer Matrix Repair

 Jamie Wells, Drexel University, The Dawning Era of Pediatric Engineering: How Bridging Interdisciplinary Knowledge Gaps Spurs Innovation

 Quanyin Hu, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Engineering Cells for Cancer Immunotherapy

Uri Hasson, Princeton University, Deep Language Models as a Cognitive Model for Natural Language Processing in the Human Brain

Ron Anafi, Penn Medicine, Combining Neural Networks with Experiments to Learn How Tumor Rhythms Influence Breast Cancer Biology and Prognosis

 

In addition, conference submissions (71 platform presentations, 140 posters) were organized into topical session in the following areas:

Biocomputing and Bioinformatics, Vascular Engineering, Tissue Engineering and Biomaterials, Cellular and Molecular Engineering, Biophotonics and Bioimaging, Mechanobiology, Immune and Cell Engineering, Medical and Piezo Devices, Biomechanics, Pediatric and Rehabilitation Engineering, Medical and Cardiac Devices, Medical Imaging, Engineering of the Extracellular Matrix, Neuroengineering I: Biology, Neuroengineering II: Brain Health and Performance, Neuroengineering III: Understanding Brain Mechanisms

 Finally, we hosted as a satellite meeting the IEEE CogSIMA (Cognitive and Computational Aspects of Situation Management): The Technologies Needed to Advance Personalized Medicine

Similar to previous editions of NEBEC, we sought to promote networking opportunities and recognition for early-career faculty development.  4 New Innovator Awards and 6 Young Scientist Awards were given, and the awardees were highlighted in special platform sessions.

 

INNOVATIONS

For the first time at NEBEC, we organized a Career Fair that had 8 exhibitors representing a diverse range of industry sectors:

Center for Breakthrough Medicines, Exponent, Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, Globus Medical, Johnson & Johnson, Medtronic, Merck, RedNucleus, Wistar Institute, Veeva

This was an extremely popular event. Afterwards, we received very positive feedback from the exhibitors and student participants.

 

High School engagement

Also new this year, we invited area high schools that serve under-represented groups to attend in order to expose them to the field of Biomedical Engineering. We provided a lecture about biomedical design process before having them review posters at the UG design competition. At a luncheon following the poster session, they discussed what they learned and how they evaluated the projects they saw. A total of 49 students and one teacher participated.

 

Diversity Panel discussion – Industry (Deepika Cattry, Bristol Myers Squibb) government/workforce Development (Rebecca Grant, Senior Director, Life Sciences and Innovation, Philadelphia Department of Commerce), and three students from under-represented groups told their stories of overcoming adversity. The session was well-attended, including good participation of academic leaders from the northeast region.


Last Modified: 10/03/2024
Modified by: Kenneth A Barbee
